title: How to Recycle Food Waste

steps.headline: Sign up for a public recycling program.
steps.description: Most major cities offer recycling programs through their Public Works department. Though some of these limit donations to paper, cans, and the like, many can handle at least some types of food. Contact your city government to ask if they offer a curbside composting program, how much it costs per month, how often they retrieve waste, and how you can sign up. After signing up, make sure to read you city’s specific recycling guidelines to know what food you can give and how to separate it properly.

steps.headline: Contact a private waste management company.
steps.description: For areas that don’t offer public recycling programs, private companies may be able to pick up the slack. Businesses like Waste Management offer international curbside programs, while local companies often provide smaller equivalents or drop-off services. Consult your local Yellow Pages for a complete list of recycling services in the area. The price of private recycling services depends on your location and specific waste management needs.

steps.headline: Bring your materials to a compost collection site.
steps.description: Even in areas with no major recycling programs, free compost collection sites may be available. Many of these sites are operated by local government branches, though some may owned by private companies or non-profit organizations. Check the collection site’s guidelines, typically available online or in person, for information on how to separate and deliver materials. In most cases, the easiest way to find collection sites is through online search engines. Some counties require a government ID to use drop-off locations. This is to limit the service to local residents. EXPERT TIP																															Kathryn Kellogg																Author, 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste								Kathryn Kellogg is the founder of goingzerowaste.com, a lifestyle website dedicated to breaking eco-friendly living down into a simple step-by-step process with lots of positivity and love. She's the author of 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste and spokesperson for plastic-free living for National Geographic. Kathryn Kellogg			Author, 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste				Composting can help reduce both methane and carbon in the atmosphere. 16% of all methane emissions in the US come from organics that are unable to decompose in landfills. Composting creates very nutrient-rich soil, which is excellent at capturing carbon.

steps.headline: Donate your recyclable materials to farms and gardens.
steps.description: In some communities, local farms and garden centers collect food waste and compost it themselves. Search online for a nearby farmer’s market or garden center, then contact them to see if anyone local offers this service. Donating to farmers and garden centers can help them reduce costs while keeping your food within the community.

steps.headline: Get a compost container.
steps.description:
To properly recycle food waste, you’ll need to purchase or create a compost container. You can construct homemade containers using fence posts and either wire mesh siding or lattice. The container should be square or round and have an open bottom. Professional compost containers come in two forms:
Compost bins, large containers that look similar to trash cans. These are small and cheap, but open at the bottom, making it difficult to turn compost. Compost tumblers, rotating cylinders that, though expensive, are easy to turn and incredibly effective.

steps.headline: Cover your container and set it in a sunny spot.
steps.description: To help it compost successfully, it’s important to keep food waste at an internal temperature of at least 135 °F (57 °C). To achieve this, place your compost container in an area where it can experience direct sunlight. If it does not have a built-in cover, place a slab of wood or tarp on top to pack in heat.

steps.headline: Set open-bottomed containers on soil.
steps.description: If your compost container has an open base, set it on a patch of soil. This allows your waste to drain properly and gives insects and microbes a chance to break down the materials. If possible, do not put your bin on paving or decking. To prevent vermin from getting into your compost, dig a 1 inch (2.5 cm) deep hole beneath your container and cover it with wire mesh.

steps.headline: Layer your bin with green and brown materials.
steps.description:
When filling your compost container, try to make even layers of green, quick rotting foods and brown, slow rotting foods. When the container is full, each type of material should make up about 50% of the total compost mixture. Examples of proper materials include:
Green items like fruit peels and pulp, vegetable peels and pulp, tea leaves and bags, coffee grounds, and carrot tops. Brown items like egg boxes and shells, nuts, tomato plants, corn starch liners, used kitchen paper, and cardboard. Do not compost bones, meat, fish, bread, dairy products, drink cartons, olive oil, plastic bags, or plastic bottles.

steps.headline: Turn your compost every two to four weeks.
steps.description: Food waste needs oxygen to decompose. To make sure all your waste gets an equal amount of air exposure, use a pitchfork to turn over your compost every few weeks. If using a tumbler, you can simply rotate the container itself with the attached crank. If you need to add more food waste, mix it in while turning the compost.

steps.headline: Water your compost bin if necessary.
steps.description: Throughout the composting process, check to make sure your pile is decomposing properly. Your food waste should be consistently damp, not dry or soaking wet. Use a hose to water dry compost, and add brown materials to soaking wet compost.

steps.headline: Wait 1 year for your food to compost.
steps.description: Food waste takes a long time to decompose. In general, expect the composting process to take between 9 months and 1 year. You compost is ready to use when the bottom is a dark, rich color.

steps.headline: Add your compost to soil.
steps.description: You can use compost to add nutrients to soil, making your yard, garden, and plants healthier. To enhance plants already in the ground, try spreading about 5 to 10 inches (13 to 25 cm) of compost over garden beds and around trees. To help new plants grow, combine your compost and soil to create a rich mix. The compost should comprise about ⅓ of the mix. In most cases, homemade compost will have rough spots where the materials did not break down completely. Use these areas as mulch for flowerbeds and shrubs.

steps.headline: Blend your fruit scraps.
steps.description: Instead of simply tossing overripe bananas, bruised pineapples, and similar fruits, turn them into a smoothie. Peel your old fruits if necessary, then throw them into a blender with ice cubes. Blend them together and try the mix. If necessary, add some fresh fruit to taste. To avoid getting sick, do not use rotten or decayed fruits.

steps.headline: Pickle vegetable scraps.
steps.description: Mix 1 cup (240 mL) of water, .5 cups (120 mL) of white, rice wine, or apple cider vinegar, 4 tablespoons (59 mL) of sugar, and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of salt in a bowl. Cut your vegetables into thin slices, sprinkle them with 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of ginger, bay leaf, or chili, and put them in a non-reactive container. Pour the vinegar solution over it, let it set for 20 minutes, then remove your pickles and store them in the fridge. Try pickling carrots, tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, onions, and similar vegetables. Though the pickling process isn’t good for old, expired food, it’s a great way to preserve vegetables before they go bad.

steps.headline: Turn stale bread into specialty dishes.
steps.description:
Most people throw bread away once it becomes stale, but old bread has a surprising number of popular, often delicious uses. To make your bread soft enough to cook with, wash it with water and bake it at 350 °F (177 °C) for about 5 minutes, or until you can tear it. Then, try:
Turning it into breadcrumbs or croutons. Using it to make stuffing. Soaking it to make bread pudding.

steps.headline: Cook with sour milk.
steps.description: Instead of throwing away sour milk, try preparing meals with it. Use it as a substitute for buttermilk when making pancakes, biscuits, and similar dishes. As long as it is pasteurized, sour milk should not make you sick.

steps.headline: Soak old bones to create broth.
steps.description: Place your bones in boiling water to blanch them, removing any impurities. Then, roast them in an oven at 450 °F (232 °C) for at least 20 minutes, or until deeply brown. Finally, put your bones in a large stockpot with 12 cups (2,800 mL) of water and crushed onion, garlic, and black pepper to taste. Cover the pot, set your burner on low, and let the mix simmer for 24 hours. For extra sweet broth, try adding sliced carrots or leeks.

text:
Using Composting Services Sign up for a public recycling program. Most major cities offer recycling programs through their Public Works department. Though some of these limit donations to paper, cans, and the like, many can handle at least some types of food. Contact your city government to ask if they offer a curbside composting program, how much it costs per month, how often they retrieve waste, and how you can sign up. After signing up, make sure to read you city’s specific recycling guidelines to know what food you can give and how to separate it properly. Contact a private waste management company. For areas that don’t offer public recycling programs, private companies may be able to pick up the slack. Businesses like Waste Management offer international curbside programs, while local companies often provide smaller equivalents or drop-off services. Consult your local Yellow Pages for a complete list of recycling services in the area. The price of private recycling services depends on your location and specific waste management needs. Bring your materials to a compost collection site. Even in areas with no major recycling programs, free compost collection sites may be available. Many of these sites are operated by local government branches, though some may owned by private companies or non-profit organizations. Check the collection site’s guidelines, typically available online or in person, for information on how to separate and deliver materials. In most cases, the easiest way to find collection sites is through online search engines. Some counties require a government ID to use drop-off locations. This is to limit the service to local residents. EXPERT TIP																															Kathryn Kellogg																Author, 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste								Kathryn Kellogg is the founder of goingzerowaste.com, a lifestyle website dedicated to breaking eco-friendly living down into a simple step-by-step process with lots of positivity and love. She's the author of 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste and spokesperson for plastic-free living for National Geographic. Kathryn Kellogg			Author, 101 Ways to Go Zero Waste				Composting can help reduce both methane and carbon in the atmosphere. 16% of all methane emissions in the US come from organics that are unable to decompose in landfills. Composting creates very nutrient-rich soil, which is excellent at capturing carbon. Donate your recyclable materials to farms and gardens. In some communities, local farms and garden centers collect food waste and compost it themselves. Search online for a nearby farmer’s market or garden center, then contact them to see if anyone local offers this service. Donating to farmers and garden centers can help them reduce costs while keeping your food within the community. Composting Food at Home Get a compost container. To properly recycle food waste, you’ll need to purchase or create a compost container. You can construct homemade containers using fence posts and either wire mesh siding or lattice. The container should be square or round and have an open bottom. Professional compost containers come in two forms:
Compost bins, large containers that look similar to trash cans. These are small and cheap, but open at the bottom, making it difficult to turn compost. Compost tumblers, rotating cylinders that, though expensive, are easy to turn and incredibly effective. Cover your container and set it in a sunny spot. To help it compost successfully, it’s important to keep food waste at an internal temperature of at least 135 °F (57 °C). To achieve this, place your compost container in an area where it can experience direct sunlight. If it does not have a built-in cover, place a slab of wood or tarp on top to pack in heat. Set open-bottomed containers on soil. If your compost container has an open base, set it on a patch of soil. This allows your waste to drain properly and gives insects and microbes a chance to break down the materials. If possible, do not put your bin on paving or decking. To prevent vermin from getting into your compost, dig a 1 inch (2.5 cm) deep hole beneath your container and cover it with wire mesh. Layer your bin with green and brown materials. When filling your compost container, try to make even layers of green, quick rotting foods and brown, slow rotting foods. When the container is full, each type of material should make up about 50% of the total compost mixture. Examples of proper materials include:
Green items like fruit peels and pulp, vegetable peels and pulp, tea leaves and bags, coffee grounds, and carrot tops. Brown items like egg boxes and shells, nuts, tomato plants, corn starch liners, used kitchen paper, and cardboard. Do not compost bones, meat, fish, bread, dairy products, drink cartons, olive oil, plastic bags, or plastic bottles. Turn your compost every two to four weeks. Food waste needs oxygen to decompose. To make sure all your waste gets an equal amount of air exposure, use a pitchfork to turn over your compost every few weeks. If using a tumbler, you can simply rotate the container itself with the attached crank. If you need to add more food waste, mix it in while turning the compost. Water your compost bin if necessary. Throughout the composting process, check to make sure your pile is decomposing properly. Your food waste should be consistently damp, not dry or soaking wet. Use a hose to water dry compost, and add brown materials to soaking wet compost. Wait 1 year for your food to compost. Food waste takes a long time to decompose. In general, expect the composting process to take between 9 months and 1 year. You compost is ready to use when the bottom is a dark, rich color. Add your compost to soil. You can use compost to add nutrients to soil, making your yard, garden, and plants healthier. To enhance plants already in the ground, try spreading about 5 to 10 inches (13 to 25 cm) of compost over garden beds and around trees. To help new plants grow, combine your compost and soil to create a rich mix. The compost should comprise about ⅓ of the mix. In most cases, homemade compost will have rough spots where the materials did not break down completely. Use these areas as mulch for flowerbeds and shrubs. Preparing Meals with Food Waste Blend your fruit scraps. Instead of simply tossing overripe bananas, bruised pineapples, and similar fruits, turn them into a smoothie. Peel your old fruits if necessary, then throw them into a blender with ice cubes. Blend them together and try the mix. If necessary, add some fresh fruit to taste. To avoid getting sick, do not use rotten or decayed fruits. Pickle vegetable scraps. Mix 1 cup (240 mL) of water, .5 cups (120 mL) of white, rice wine, or apple cider vinegar, 4 tablespoons (59 mL) of sugar, and 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of salt in a bowl. Cut your vegetables into thin slices, sprinkle them with 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of ginger, bay leaf, or chili, and put them in a non-reactive container. Pour the vinegar solution over it, let it set for 20 minutes, then remove your pickles and store them in the fridge. Try pickling carrots, tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, onions, and similar vegetables. Though the pickling process isn’t good for old, expired food, it’s a great way to preserve vegetables before they go bad. Turn stale bread into specialty dishes. Most people throw bread away once it becomes stale, but old bread has a surprising number of popular, often delicious uses. To make your bread soft enough to cook with, wash it with water and bake it at 350 °F (177 °C) for about 5 minutes, or until you can tear it. Then, try:
Turning it into breadcrumbs or croutons. Using it to make stuffing. Soaking it to make bread pudding. Cook with sour milk. Instead of throwing away sour milk, try preparing meals with it. Use it as a substitute for buttermilk when making pancakes, biscuits, and similar dishes. As long as it is pasteurized, sour milk should not make you sick. Soak old bones to create broth. Place your bones in boiling water to blanch them, removing any impurities. Then, roast them in an oven at 450 °F (232 °C) for at least 20 minutes, or until deeply brown. Finally, put your bones in a large stockpot with 12 cups (2,800 mL) of water and crushed onion, garlic, and black pepper to taste. Cover the pot, set your burner on low, and let the mix simmer for 24 hours. For extra sweet broth, try adding sliced carrots or leeks.
